text: Jail Breakers () is a 2002 South Korean comedy film directed by Kim Sang-jin and starring Sol Kyung-gu, Cha Seung-won and Song Yoon-ah. It was a box office hit with a total of 3,073,919 admissions nationwide, making it the 4th highest grossing Korean film of 2002. ==Plot== Two long-term prisoners manage to break out of jail by tunneling underneath the prison wall with a spoon. Upon returning to society, they read in the newspaper that they are scheduled to be pardoned under a special amnesty on the very next day. The desperate warden agrees to pretend nothing happened if they can break back into prison unnoticed. ==Cast== * Sol Kyung-gu as Yu Jae-pil * Cha Seung-won as Choi Mu- seok * Song Yoon-ah as Han Gyeong-sun * Kang Sung-jin as Yong Mun-sin * Kang Shin-il as Prison warden * Yoo Hae-jin as Police officer * Lee Hee-do as Director * Park Jeong-hak as FM * Jang Tae-sung as Cheol-gu ==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" ! scope="col" |Year ! scope="col" |Award ! scope="col" |Category ! scope="col" |Recipients ! scope="col" |Result ! scope="col" |Ref. |- | rowspan="2" | 2002 ! rowspan="2" scope="row" |23rd Blue Dragon Film Awards | Best Supporting Actress | Song Yoon-ah | | rowspan="2" | |- | Best Screenplay | Park Jung-woo | |- | rowspan="4" | 2003 ! scope="row" | 39th Baeksang Arts Awards | Best Actor | Cha Seung-won | | |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | 40th Grand Bell Awards | Best Supporting Actress | Song Yoon-ah | | |- | Best Cinematography | Jeong Kwang- seok | | |- ! scope="row" | 11th Chunsa Film Art Awards | Best Supporting Actress | Song Yoon-ah | | |- |} ==References== ==External links== * * * Category:2002 films Category:Korean-language films Category:South Korean films Category:South Korean buddy films Category:South Korean comedy films Category:Films directed by Kim Sang-jin (film director)
